#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=3. Discussion
#Text=The statistical analysis of the collected data at each visit shows a very good trend for hydrogel containing trehalose and ceramides based ingredient at each visit :
#Text=Evaporimetry ( Transepidermal Water Loss ( TEWL ) )
#Text=Evaporimetry was used to detect any influence on the water barrier function of the skin following application of ceramides and trehalose based ingredient hydrogel and placebo hydrogel .
#Text=Corneometry ( Hydration )
#Text=In order to measure the amount of water present in the stratum corneum and the skin barrier condition , hydration has been evaluated through Corneometry .

#Text=Moreover , the T-test applied to hydrogel containing ceramides and trehalose based ingredient and placebo formula gave a statistically significant difference between them at each visit , always showing better results for the hydrogel containing ceramides and trehalose based ingredient .

#Text=The double-blind , placebo-controlled study was performed to assess , by corneometry and evaporimetry , the barrier normalizing efficacy of a topical product containing trehalose and ceramides to alleviate skin dryness on limbs .
#Text=The study results show a significant moisturizing effect of the ingredient at each visit , both versus baseline and versus the placebo control ( p < 0.01 ) .
#Text=For the application site of topical cosmetic formula containing a trehalose and ceramides based ingredient :
#Text=( 1 ) Transepidermal water loss ( TEWL ) value shows a reduction of −54 % after 4 weeks (
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=) .
#Text=( 2 ) Hydration shows an increase of 102 % after 4 weeks (
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=) .

#Text=Such results point out the significant moisturizing effect after using the cosmetic under examination and go well with the rationale of the formulation , based on ingredients able to moisturize rapidly the skin and recover the cutaneous barrier to allow it to better hold the water present into its outer layers .
#Text=In vivo evaluation of the efficacy of a formulation for atopic and very dry skin ( Xerosis ) was done .
#Text=An example of one topical formulation for atopic dermatitis ( Table 1 ) based on trehalose and ceramides based ingredient is reported below for illustrative and non-limiting purposes .

#Text=Purpose of the test : To provide active substances through a form that allows a prompt release and an effective amount in atopic dermatitis , characterized by a deteriorated functionality of the barrier , an increased transepidermal water loss ( TEWL ) and a significant xerosis , as well as in the case of pathologies associated with a local subcutaneous microcirculation disorder .
#Text=The efficacy of a topical cosmetic formulation containing trehalose and ceramides in comparison to a placebo has been evaluated .
#Text=Mean values , standard deviations , and variations were calculated for each set of values .

#Text=Following the results of normality test ( Kolmogorov – Smirnov test ) , the instrumental data ( T0 , T4 weeks ) and the variations ( T4 weeks-T0 ) were statistically compared by means of t -test for parametric and dependent data .
#Text=In all cases , the groups of data were considered statistically different for a probability value p < 0.05 .

#Text=Protocol of double-blind study : the product containing trehalose and ceramides ingredient and the placebo was applied on the forearms by 20 volunteers of either sex ( 1 male and 19 females with an average age of 50 years ) with atopic and very dry skin ( xerosis ) , twice a day , for 4 weeks .
#Text=During the study , subjects were instructed to wash their body using their current skin care regimen and to not apply the tested products on any other site than the prescribed ones .
#Text=For the whole duration of the test , the subjects were not allowed to use different products on the forearms and instructed to avoid UV exposure .

#Text=Furthermore , the side of application ( left or right forearm ) of the two formulations ( cream containing trehalose and ceramides based ingredient and placebo ) were randomized among the volunteers .
#Text=Each sample was labeled “ right ” or “ left ” , indicating the side of application of the product .
#Text=The assignment of subject number and subsequent placement on the randomization chart were made in order of appearance at the study center on the first day .
#Text=The products were given to the subjects in anonymous containers which did not provide any information about the treatment .
#Text=The comparisons evidenced statistically significant differences between studied ingredient and placebo for both parameters ( hydration and TEWL ) .
#Text=This means that the improvements observed in the active area were statistically higher than the improvements observed in the placebo area .
#Text=Instrumental measurements of skin hydration and transepidermal water loss ( TEWL ) were performed on a selected area ( 9 cm2 ) of the forearms at the baseline and after 4 weeks of treatment .
#Text=Skin Hydration

#Text=A statistically significant increase in the mean basal values of skin hydration was evidenced after 4 weeks of application of both the ceramides and trehalose based ingredient cream and the placebo product ( Table 2 ) .
#Text=A statistically significant difference between ceramides and trehalose based ingredient cream and placebo product was detected after 4 weeks of treatment (
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=) .
#Text=The cream containing trehalose and ceramides based ingredient is able to improve skin hydration if compared to placebo .
#Text=Transepidermal Water Loss ( TEWL )
